org.note: Wife Robt Quadryng. Possibly St in own right

address.addrLine: Res: Parish of St Agnes & St Anne

org.note: Husb Dionisia; father of Henry & Margaret; possibly stepfather of Alice
Registered press 9/6/1837. Deacon at Garland St Baptist Church for 33 years
Apprenticed to John Wallis 1770
Partnership with George Paine dissolved on 7/7/1845

address.addrLine: 48 Upper St. John st, Fitzroy sq.

org.note: ? related to Rachel Quarmby
? related to Joseph Quarmby
Editions found in Hove reference library.
insolvent debtor in Debtors' Prison for London & Middlesex 1850
Ptd/published Rev William Henry Coombes's `Life of St Francis of Sales' (1812) & John Davis's `Concise History of the Cathedral Church of St Andrew in Wells' (1814)

address.addrLine: King and Constitution Tavern, Marble St

org.note: Master of Robert Viney 1716
The manor & paper mills at Byfleet were settled on Queen Katherine as jointure in 1673; mills were known as King's Mills
'upward of 5000 books'

address.addrLine: Printers' st. Shoe lane & 9 East Harding st.

org.note: See COEFFIN, Martin

In Dartford parish records from 1673; entries suggest he was at the Dartford Mill worked by William Wood not the Dartford Mill worked by William Blackwell. He married Ann Wood in 1673. Possibly related to William Quelch. One of 14 papermakers who opposed the Company of White Papermakers in 1690. Edward Spycer, Jeremiah Francis, Edward Quelch, William Harris, George Gill, Robert Slade, William Blackwell, John Slocombe, John West, Richard West, Thomas Morris, William Russell, Alexander Russell, James West.

address.addrLine: 24 East St, Walworth (1828). 4 Butcherhall La, Fleet St (1832). 40 Little Charlotte St. Blackfriars rd (1834-50)

org.note: Registered press 9/9/1834. Succeeded by Mrs Kezia Quelch
Mill formerly held by George Hager. Assessed at Â£40 for mill in 1698. Mill passed to Richard Archer by 1701
Successor to William Smith. Insured utensils etc.at West Mills in 1748 (SFIP 112989)

address.addrLine: 40 Little Charlotte St, Blackfriars Rd, Southwark

org.note: Possibly widow Henry Quelch
Mill possibly founded by George Edwards. Mill passed to Mr Beckford by 1708
William Quelch of Loose & John Terry of Hollingbourne insured Hollingbourne Old Mill in tenure of latter in 1739 (SFIP 82644). W Quelch & J Terry insured goods etc.in 1740 (SFIP 86467)
Reading Poll Book

Successor to William Blackwell at mill c1702. Probably moved to Basted Mill, Wrotham by 1723. Daughter Sarah married Clement Taylor, PP of Wrotham. William Quelch of Wrotham owned & insured another Dartford Mill c1736>

Master of William Buttershaw. Insured his hse & paper mill at Dartford in tenure of Richard Archer in 1736 (SFIP 72367). In 1741 insured 2 adjoining Dartford mills occupied by himself & John Terry (SFIP 90038)
Successor to William Harris. Insured Hollingbourne Mill in 1739. Insured hse & mill etc.in Loose in 1741 (SFIP 87455). Master of Abraham Musgrave (1743>). Mill passed to William Quelch II by 1746
Bought Mill from Richard Archer. Insured mill with R Archer as tenant in 1736 (SFIP 72367). After R Archer was bankrupt (1740) William Quelch divided property into 2 mills run by J Terry & himself
Successor to William Quelch sr. Insured hse in Loose in tenure of Stephen Scott, & the paper mill in 1747 (SFIP 104723). Succeeeded by S Scott in 1747. Also at Dartford Mills
Successor to mill worked by William Quelch I 1741>. Insured mill in 1747 (SFIP 109027). Master of John Collins 1748. Possibly died in 1775 or 1777. Mill passed to James Terry & Thomas Bludgen by 1779
See Joshua Carby, Thomas Clarke, Charles Morgan, Joshua Carby Radway
Master of David Hall 1745
Apprenticed to Philip Oriel. Free Merchant Taylors' Co; livery in 1785. SFIP 463755 (1782). Master of Ed Parbury (1784>); John Sampson (1785>); John Turner Smith (1785>)

address.addrLine: 13 Little Guildford St. 42 Bowling Green La. 43 Fashion St. 5 Weston Pl
91 Old Market St (1829), 86 Old Market St

org.note: Trading as Messrs Quick & Co (1776)

address.addrLine: 2 North st. mews, Fitzroy sq. & 70 Great Titchfield st.

org.note: Published Manx Sun' (Friday). Printed & published Archibald Cregeen's `Dictionary of the Manx Language' (1835). Possibly the same as John Quiggin II
Printed Revd J T Clarke's edition of `Lioar dy Hymnyn' (1846) [Manx hymnbook] Possibly the same as John Quiggin

Father of J A Quinton. In 1858 business run by widow, Mrs M Quinton
Son of John Quinton. A freelance jman printer (dates of activity unknown)
Mo J A Quinton. Widow & successor to John Quinton
b Lancaster, aged 17
